comment.author: 55785872@N00
comment._content: This must be 1914, as the ship was launched in 1913 and made only few trips to the US before being caught up by the war in NY in July 1914. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Vaterland

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: From, NYT, May 22, 1914, Friday query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E01E5DA113FE6... "VATERLAND ARRIVES FIGHTS TIDE 4 HOURS; World's Biggest Steamship Impeded by River Craft on Ending Maiden Voyage." However, the Bain sticker certainly appears to say 7/3/13 and the picture looks a lot like a painting rather than a photograph to me. The two photos close in the Bain series look like publicity shots. So I wonder if these are associated with publicity following her launch, which was on April 3, 1913. Interestingly, www.greatoceanliners.net/vaterland.html indicates that she was originally to be called Europa, and that seems to be the name underneath the hand-written "Vaterland." The same web page has a different color scheme in a photo and makes a point of the Vaterland not having a figurehead. Those are certainly things easily changed during the year of fitting out.

comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content: Not to be confused with "Vaderland" which was running from Antwerp to NY a few years earlier.

comment.author: 80309472@N00
comment._content: Look at it full size, this is a photograph of a painting, yes?

comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content:
photo.keith, what makes you think it's a painting?  Looks like a photo negative to me.

swanq, lots of props for desciphering what was under "vaterland".  Strange that someone at the Bain news service felt it necessary to etch in the negative.

comment.author: 66679426@N00
comment._content: It's fairly obvious this is a painting.

comment.author: 7471115@N08
comment._content: Yes, definitely a painting, perhaps for a postcard(?). Also, the Vaterland wasn't completed with an elaborate figurehead as depicted; only her sister the Imperator had such a fixture - and lost it shortly thereafter in a storm.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Yes, this is most likely a photograph of an illustration with some handwriting on the negative.  We'll add your observations to the source catalog, with the caution of "probably" until more information turns up. Thanks!

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content: most likely a painting, possibly for promotional materials or post cards to promote the Hamburg Line.  The SS Amerika could be the ship on the left heading away.  Wiki uses this image as a "painting"
